What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List:
-what other aspects around food to consider (behavior, culture, identity, environment)
-how food can be used to bring people together or push people apart
-LOT of interesting readings!
I began to understand what the field of cultural anthropology was, and I was able to build a basic foundation of research skills to conduct an anthropological study.
An understanding of culture through a diverse lense of senses and perspectives.
-maybe there could be a brief bullet-point outline of some things we could focus on each readings each week, so that we know what to look out for in readings

Strengths: Diversity in weekly readings, small discussion group style where there's no apprehension of sharing an opinion, material can be universally understood between students of all majors, backgrounds, and years. Small break in between reading discussions during class. Prof Merrifield can lead discussion well throughout the class with interesting outside info, invites other students to lead discussion as well
Weaknesses: Class would be more engaging if spread out over two days, talking about two readings for nearly two hours can be draining especially after a long night/day

The biggest weakness is the how the class is structured: two straight hours of discussion. I do not think that speaking with other students about the readings for two hours was the best use of that time. We were tired and out of ideas after about an hour, and as a result, a lot of time was just lost to awkward silences where people were trying to figure out what to say. I think that giving Professor Merrifield (her knowledge is a huge strength of the course) more time to lecture in the two hours would have been much more productive. The biggest strength of this course was the readings because they were relatively concise and very, very interesting.
Absolutely! It was so much fun talking about food for 2 hrs every week, would definitely recommend it. Always got to talk about fun things and read fun things.

Yes! Redefines how you think about what you put in front of your plate 3-4 times a day, helps you inspire fascinating conversations over food with your friends/family/strangers. Learn much about food and what shapes it for a couple of hours of reading a week and 3 papers spread over the semester.

If this course was still based on two hours of pure discussion, I would not recommend it. If the structure was changed to incorporate some other teaching methods instead of pure discussion, I would recommend it.
yes, the proffessor helps understand the readings and provokes insightful thinking.
